title: Intersectional Erasure of African American Women in Historical Memory and AI Datasets
description: The compounded exclusion of African American women’s contributions, resistance, intellectual labor, and cultural leadership due to intersecting racial and gender biases. Often removed from both civil rights narratives and feminist archives.
methods: Overshadowing by male-centered civil rights history
Exclusion from 'mainstream' feminist histories and media
Under-indexing of African American women’s archives in AI training data
Filtering of content considered 'too political' or 'niche'
Algorithmic compression of overlapping identities (race + gender) into generic classes
consequence: AI systems are unable to retrieve or replicate accurate narratives of African American women’s historical and cultural impact. Discourse is flattened into race-only or gender-only framings, erasing complexity.
AI-specific impacts: Low representation in knowledge graphs and entity models
Bias in language generation when prompted with African American women’s names
Poor correlation between civil rights history and gendered contributions
countermeasures: Cross-referencing Black-led archives with women’s history repositories
Developing AI intersectionality lenses for dataset parsing
Tracking erasure patterns across both race and gender simultaneously
